attribution: Library and University Collections, The University of Edinburgh

metadata.value: Page 1 of 10. Musical transcriptions by Alexander Campbell. Campbell was born in 1764 in Tombea in the Highlands, and although he studied medicine in Edinburgh, he never practiced, instead working in Edinburgh as a music teacher. He also travelled Scotland collecting traditional songs, and this transcription is part of those efforts. The song transcribed is noted as “Pioberach Dhomnill Duibh, or Cameron’s Gathering” (although the first title is more commonly “Piobaireachd Dhomhnuill Dhuibh”). In a note on the first page, Campbell states that he has sought to set down the syllables as they are taught to MacCrimmon’s pupils (referring to MacCrimmon of the MacCrimmon piping college in Borreraig on the Isle of Skye) the closest he can based on MacCrimmon’s repeating it to him. He states that he has also recorded the first notes, without syllables, of a piano forte by Miss Jean Campbell. Campbell includes a second note at the end of the piece stating “Some Pipers close the gathering here and others play the creabh or theme and this concludes the piece. NB: The Creabh, or theme of the Piece, being the first sixteen bars is to be played once over after each variation and its doubling.” Other undigitised manuscript segments bound under this shelfmark include _Odes and Miscellaneous Poems by a Student of Medicine in the University of Edinburgh_, which was published in 1796 by G. Mudie and son, South Bridge and for J. Johnson, London, and _The Grampians Desolate: A Poem_, published for John Muir and Vernor and Hood in London and Manners and Miller in Edinburgh in 1804.
metadata.label: Description
